content: jeremy has changed my life a couple years ago i fell through a
window that cut deep through my forearm and has left
me with permanent nerve damage occasionally numbness and paralysis and
a case of the shakes bmc mentioned his reclined arms on the
chest paint position and today i base coated my first
consistent clean model in years i've never been so thankful to have
a hobby back in my life as this this has legit reopened
so much of my life to me and i don't know how to express
how grateful i am all right this seems important and i think it's
finally time this topic gets its own video
[Applause]
hey guys welcome back to blackmagic
craft i have on a few occasions mentioned my difficulty dealing with a
handshake in videos and a few ways that i kind of
cope with it but i thought it would finally be time
to pack up a bunch of the things that i do to
help me put them all together into one video
in the hopes that maybe it will help some of you while i reflected on the
various things that i could include in this video i painted up a sweet little
vampire miniature from the sponsor of this week's video
my friends at loot studios there's a lot of different things that
can cause shaky hands some of the causes are temporary things
that can be easily changed by simple lifestyle choices and some of the
causes can be medical and those medical causes
can be from a wide variety of medical issues so some of these tips may help
and some of them may not i am not a doctor
and i don't want any of this advice to come off as recommendations
and ways to avoid dealing with what could be a serious medical issue if you
suffer from shaky hands to the point where it's interfering with the things
that you do it's probably a good idea to at least
talk to your doctor about them personally my shakes are caused by
an essential tremor essential tremors are
a degenerative neurological disorder that are
actually pretty common mine will likely never get better as i age it's probably
only going to get worse there's no silver bullet cure for this there are
things that i found that i can do in my life
to improve it these are just the things that i have found
to work for me they are highly personal but i think they are all worth at least
trying
what we put in our bodies or forget to put in our bodies can greatly affect
tremors if you're trying to paint a mini on an
empty stomach even as a healthy person with no
medically caused shakes you may find yourself battling with shaky hands
this can be greatly worsened if you have insufficient food in your system
but have also had like three cups of coffee caffeine can cause
minor shakes in just about everyone especially if they haven't eaten
if you find yourself shaking worse than usual reflect on what fuel
your body does or doesn't have in its system
may be time to stop and grab a bite to eat for essential tremors
a balanced and healthy diet is one of the first things you can do to decrease
your shakes a small amount of alcohol can also
decrease tremors caused by certain things
personally my doctor recommended alcohol in moderation
when i'm really struggling with my shakes one beer in the evening when
painting makes a big difference for me of course you've got to be old enough to
legally consume alcohol should be doing so in moderation and the
source of your tremors or shakes should be determined by a doctor before
trying something that could possibly make them worse or be harmful
sleep can also be another factor in this area
while not body fuel so to speak being sleep deprived is something that can
really elevate the severity of my shakes stress is another factor that really
elevates my shakes so being well rested can help both with
the sleep factor and the stress factor
i can't overemphasize how important this
is for me dealing with my shakes i think every painter regardless
of having shaky hands or not owes it to themselves
to have a comfortable painting handle while working on a miniature
it's far more ergonomic and comfortable and will prevent cramps in your hand
and fatigue while painting for shakes though having that added weight
and a wide grip on something will really help it's quite common for people
suffering from more severe tremors induced by disorders like
parkinson's to use weighted tools to help ease some of the
burden when performing daily tasks i don't have a great medical
understanding of why this is but i know from personal experience that
my shakes are a lot worse when lifting or holding very
light objects having a wide painting handle with some weight
is essential for me as a painter now there's a lot of specialty hobby handles
out on the market that you can try but you don't necessarily need to go
that route if you don't want to personally i found
that pill bottles or the empty bottles that my super glue comes in
make for great painting handles i like to fill them with sand
so that they have a really nice weight to them this also keeps them steady when
putting your mini down on the table what actual item will work best for you
in terms of size and weight could take some experimentation but it's
worth taking that time to experiment on try bottles chunks of wood pvc
pipe or the fancy painting handles whatever you've got available
just try it all i know is that when i stopped using tiny corks to hold my
minis while painting and switched to bigger handles my
experience was greatly improved now let's take a second
to highlight the amazing sponsor that made this video possible my friends at
loot studios this is like the fifth video i've
partnered on with them and i'm always happy to do so because they make such
lovely models to work on loot is a monthly service that you can join for
only 15 bucks a month to get access to tons of beautiful and
inspiring models you can print at home on your 3d printer each month is a
different theme this month's theme is vampires a subject
matter that is universally useful for all sorts of tabletop gaming
be it in a fantasy or modern setting there's always an opportunity to make
players face off against a bloodthirsty villain
their models come pre-supported making it a breeze to get going on your resin
printer even if you have very little experience
i'm still a novice 3d printer and i haven't taken the time to learn the ins
and outs of setting supports properly and because their files come
pre-supported i've been able to print several of their minis without any issue
all the models come in both 32 millimeter gaming scale and the larger
75 millimeter scale for display painting each month you get a variety of heroes
villains and decorative items and if it's your first month using the
service you also get a huge welcome pack full of really sweet tavern themed items
i'll put a link in the video description so you can check them out for yourselves
i really really love their models and how they've set up their service
and this certainly won't be the last time i work on a loop model
this is going to be the area you receive
the most advice and tips on everyone has their
favorite painting position that they swear
by to help keep themselves steady and you kind of gotta just try a bunch of
them before you find the one that works for you
a lot of people recommend elbows on the table and while this may be useful for
people not coping with serious shakes i found
it mostly to be counterproductive for those of us that do
personally i find that this position actually makes my shakes worse
as for some reason putting pressure on my elbows somehow
increases my tremor but your mileage may vary
well there are a lot of positions you can try the important thing
in any of them is finding a way to centralize your hands to your body mass
and keep your hands moving in unison if they're gonna move
one good approach is to keep your two hands solidly touching together while
painting this can be comfortably done by creating
a sort of cup shape with your hands and then using the
thumb and index finger of your dominant hand to do your brush work
an alternative to the elbows on the table bracing that some people use and i
think is probably more effective as to use a table to push your arms
towards essentially positioning yourself in such
a way as to create forward pressure from your body towards your forearms which
are set in place against an immovable object
while this actually does help reduce my shakes i've
never been able to find a way to get comfortable enough doing it for long
periods and being comfortable while painting is
really important if your body is in discomfort not only is it
displeasurable but it may be an indication of doing
some small harm by straining your body remember when
your body hurts it's trying to tell you that something
is wrong so i've come to use and love the otter position i like to
sit back in a comfy chair put my legs up and hold my arms close to
my chest then using that same hand cupping method
i discussed earlier i hold the model and paint it fairly close to my face
not only does it reduce my shaking by a massive amount
it's also a position that i can sit in comfortably for many hours
and i want to mention the elastic band method while i found that it didn't work
well for me i can see how it might work for a lot of
people the idea is simple use an elastic band around your wrist to
bind some of your fingers on your painting hand
this creates some form of pressure that counteracts
what might be causing a tremor i think it acts in a similar way
to holding something heavy without actually holding something heavy
i know from my own trials with this method that it did
instantly reduce some of my tremors but like some of the positions that i
mentioned earlier i found it to get a little uncomfortable for
long periods so it didn't work for me but it's absolutely worth trying as it
might be the magic solution for you
normally i like to promote a message of using
cheap things when possible and i don't like the idea of people getting obsessed
over or having the best tools or paints or
whatever but there is something to be said for using things that work more
easily because of the quality when already facing a challenge like
shaky hands using good paintbrushes or paint is not
going to do anything to stop your shakes but using things that simply work
better is gonna remove one more obstacle getting between you
and a decent outcome when you are already working at a disadvantage of
having shaky hands any disadvantage that you can remove is
gonna make your life easier you can absolutely paint minis with
crappy brushes and crappy paint but it's going to be harder a very
skilled painter can paint a mini better with craft paint
then a poor painter can paint a mini with the best paint but
that's because of their skill there's no denying that paint designed
for miniatures applies more easily and more consistently
than 50 cent craft paint that you got at walmart if you're already fighting
shakes fighting chalky heavy bodied large pigmented craft paint
is just gonna make your life even harder same goes for brushes
if you're trying to paint a tiny detail with a horrible paintbrush that looks
like a worn-out broom it's gonna be hard for anyone and nearly
impossible for someone struggling with a tremor give yourself
every advantage possible and in terms of brushes you
don't need to go out and buy fancy sable hair brushes
although i will say they help immensely you should get some cheaper
detail brushes in bulk quantities so you can replace
them as soon as they start to develop hooked or frayed tips painting details
with shaky hands is like trying to hit a moving target
at the very least try to ensure your arrow tip is pointy when aiming
relaxing while painting is going to help
with a lot of types of tremors this means being comfortable but it also
means being calm put on a movie podcast or
music that will calm you down not something that's going to stress you out
while listening to it and elevate your blood pressure or heart rate
maybe don't listen to the news while painting
make painting a meditative time and stay as chill as possible while doing it
this also means being aware of your breathing
don't hold your breath while painting people often tell me to do this to get
over my shakes and i'm sorry but that's not very good advice talk to
a sniper a sharpshooter someone really skilled at
ballistics or archery see what they have to say about holding
their breath while trying to line up and make a difficult shot
don't hold your breath instead focus on breathing calmly
slowly and deliberately breathe in breathe out nice and slow
nice and calm when trying to get that tiny eye
painted practice getting the brush stroke done
on a calm and collected exhale while none of this advice i've offered
is going to be a silver bullet and some of it might not work for you
dealing with shakes or tremors while hobbying requires a holistic approach
and a bit of trial and error i hope that at least something here will
help you with your personal struggles and at the very least i hope
me talking about my struggles openly removes some of the stigma or
embarrassment that some people might have about their shaky
hands if you found this video helpful give it a like and share it with someone
that may find it useful if you have any of your own tricks that
you use for coping with shaky hands please by all means share them in the
comments section and if you want to grab some tools for your hobby consider doing
so through my essential equipment page on blackmagicraft.ca
shopping through that page helps fund the production of videos like this
and of course if you really get value out of the content i make consider
helping me continue doing it by supporting the channel on patreon i'd
love to have you as a member of the blackmagicraft fellowship
that post that i shared at the beginning of this video was from a patron
in my fellowship group and it shows the kind of compassionate and caring
attitude that makes up that group we'd love to have you
as the newest member cheers and thanks for watching
you
